text: hi everyone yesterday no tano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new remy wolf
album juno this is the debut full-length
lp of singer songwriter producer remy
wolf the anticipation for this record it
feels like it's been building up forever
she's had a couple of big viral hits
some respectable eps and a lot of her
audience growth happened over the course
of a concert-less pandemic remy also
teased about half the record in the
lead-up to this lp and pretty much every
track sounded like a wild noisy party in
the back of a thrift shop not in a
macklemore kind of way more like a two
d-pop sellers ready to kill each other
over a vintage nascar shirt kind of way
needless to say remy's music has a lot
of personality not just because of her
vocal range and incredible versatility
she sounds just as comfortable rapping
as she does singing but you've also got
to give it to the eclectic mashes of
rock rap pop funk r b on this thing
sometimes the way remy brings
different styles together reminds me of
early beck at points we also get the
wild attitude and the instrumental
density of a tune yards record or the
nimble vocal licks and detailed
harmonies of a dirty projector's record
but even those direct comparisons aren't
that close to the full experience of
juno there's so much commotion happening
on any given track from this lp it's
difficult to sum up but pretty much all
the chaos is calculated to fit very
snugly into these incredible grooves and
infectious hooks cause underneath all
the eccentricity remy's hitting us with
on her vocals on her instrumentation
there is a steady hand forming these
complex multi-genre fusions and the
track list on this thing is just bops
right from the first one the soaring
vocal harmonies fat drums fuzzy guitars
and glossy keys on liquor store set remy
up to pull off a really funny rap first
that runs essentially like a character
portrait there's a real sadness and
urgency to remy singing as well on this
chorus that surprisingly cuts through
all the color and quirk of the
instrumental that quirk however does get
turned up a bit on the following anthony
kiedis a song whose eccentric production
is juxtaposed against these lyrics about
uh pandemic isolation and going nuts as
a result of that in a way and i love how
on the verses vocally and instrumentally
there's already so much going on there's
so many dry up front loud layers right
in your face but even from there remy
manages to push it to another level with
these choruses that really blossom and
layer up with these grand non-vocal
harmonies and some a very loud guitar
somehow this record manages to make its
generally claustrophobic sound feel huge
and for remy that sonic claustrophobia i
don't even see it as a bad thing just
everything on this record is so close
it's so upfront it's so in your face
there's nothing and nowhere to hide the
slick and funny wyd is a great r b
tinged cut with more impressive and
dynamic vocal work remy's kind of
covering all the bases on this one from
melodic rap flows to cartoony chants on
gorilla the throbbing synths tight beats
and bright harmony hits build a bubbly
backdrop for remy to paint this picture
about this uh crush this confusion that
she's thrown into as a result of this
guy who is is leaving an impression then
quiet on set which might be my favorite
track on the entire record this one has
almost an nerd vibe to it off of its
gritty and zany mix of synths and beats
remy flexes her personality on this one
through her pen with some really bizarre
and uncompromising bars the orgy at five
guys one is is a lot i don't think the
record is all insanity though there are
points at which instrumentally or
emotionally remy does hit pockets of
introspection or subtlety the song
volcano for example may have this
blaring siren hook to it but the
measured singing and lyrics laced
throughout the verses of this track
explore heartbreak and self-doubt in a
way that's really earnest and relatable
there's also a reflective tone on the
song grumpy old man where remy is
singing about her defensiveness and
emotions that make her almost a cranky
person to be around at least how it
comes off in the song which i think
causes this comparison to a grumpy old
man it's a good chorus but like for some
reason toward the end uh remy starts
singing it in
sort of a southern accent with a yee-haw
ad-lib i do love this one but there are
some points on the record where i think
maybe remy is doing a tad bit too much
the constant falsetto vocal harmonies on
the song buttermilk are a little grating
plus i don't think the hook on this one
really pops considering just how
repetitive the instrumental is it
doesn't progress or contrast all that
well from one section of the song to the
next then with the song sally some of
the auto-tuned vocal leads on this one
are
a little tangy it's kind of like licking
a 9-volt
the song itself is fine
i like the lyrical tone of it a lot but
i i don't think that auto-tune or just
the boldness of the vocal on this one
fits how low-key and somber the song and
instrumentation really are then the
closer street you live on is another
moment that i thought was a little over
the top because all the strange vocal
manipulations to
remy singing on this track it does
distract from the song itself quite a
bit it's a tad unflattering and for a
singer as as bold as remy may be
unnecessary though i do generally
appreciate the experimentation of this
track and others maybe it's something
that if she were to take another whack
at it could be tweaked to sound more
interesting and look while i do have
reservations about several of the tracks
on this lp considering stylistically
what's worked for remy so far plus the
fact that this is a debut where she is
still tweaking her sound a bit i would
rather an album here where she is doing
unapologetically too much than uh giving
us too little out of fear or hesitation
so yeah while the songs on this lp i
think are a little spotty toward the end
damn it's got a great start and i love
the vast majority of the tracks here and
overall it's a really impressive debut
that i hope rolls into uh even more
impressive records down the road i'm
feeling a strong seven to a light eight
on this one tran position have you given
this album a listen did you love it did
you hate it what would you rate it
you're the best you're the best what
should i review next hit the like if you
like please subscribe and please don't
cry hit the bell as well over here next
to my head it's another video that you
can check out hit that up or the link to
subscribe to the channel anthony fantano
remy wolf of forever
